An-anokon din ka lawa rin. Ogbulungon di: His body was refreshed. He was satisfying his body in the water.
Ka doun kunakun, igtotomug to homoy no i: The leaves called kunakun are fed into the fire as a treatment for bugs.
Ka mgo otow, ogkabulusbulus ka og-amut t: The people are being drawn together to attend the Kaamulan celebration because there are things to see.
Ko ogbugsi on ka bulutut, ogsolug to lan: When the boil bursts, the pus will be mixed with blood.
Nigbunggù to boi ka ulu to alu-an no nam: The woman pressed the head of the mudfish to break its neck and so it died.
Du-on otow no nigparigus no nigtinugpù n: There was a person who went bathing and dove headfirst and broke his neck because he hit his head [against something].
Ka bungkal, songsong to tagan to apug. B: A rattan seive is the plug of a lime container. It is made of rattan and is a seive for the lime.
Ko du-on siak no na-atangan on, ko oggul: If there is a side-stream which has been blocked, if a person breaks up the blockage, it has been cleared.
Ko hondo-i ogkataman ka hikot to asu, du: Wherever the tether of the dog ends, that is where he will be limited.
Du-on otow no nalagak ka salapi din no d: There was a person who lost two hundred pesos of his money. He came to an end of looking for it but didn't find it.
Ko du-on duma ta no du-on batasan no kon: If we have a companion who has conduct which cannot be changed, we give up on teaching him to do good.
Nigbungku-an on to doctor si Ann Joy. Ag: The doctor ran out of options for Ann Joy. Even if there was something they could do to save her, she would still die.
Ka otow no ogkakamot, du-on patamanan di: A person who is making a field, has an ending of the edge of his field and that is how far he will allow his field to extend.
Ka lubid to asu ka ogpakabungku oyow du-: The rope is that which is setting a limit so that it will not go any farther.
Ka kayu no lawa-an, ko du-on on ogbungul: As for the lawa-an tree, when there is a lump of sap on the lawa-an tree, when it is hardened, that is the pitch which can make a light.
Ko iam on og-anak ka boi no ungod oglang: When a woman newly gives birth and is always bleeding, we knead the lower abdomen so that the uterus will contract and the bleeding will stop.
Ka bakotin no ogsusu, ungud ogbunagon ka: When a piglet nurses, it is always pumping the breasts of the mother so that they will fill with milk.
Ko ogdugmo-on ka babuy no ogkaboros, ogk: If a pregnant pig is rammed into by another pig, it will miscarry and that with which it was pregnant will be discharged.
Ka sikan no bunanat, ogmoon-ing on no og: That propagate, it will become many and spread there in our place.
Kagi to songo otow, \"Hondo-i ka nig-ala: One person says, "From where did you transport that seed?" I say, "From Maguimon. They asked for that seed which they will also propagate."
Pakabunanat ka mgo ambow; oghilabot to k: The rats will propagate; it mated with another rat which was not the same as itself.
Ogpakabubunat kid to ambow no songo lo-i: We happened to have propagated another kind of rat.
Ko ogsalop ka allow, ogkabunbunan to ogm: When the sun goes down, darkness covers the earth.
That which erases the footprints is the rain.
Ka otow no ogbubunbun, ogpa-abin to song: The person who hides a fault transfers the blame to someone else.
Ko du-on otow no ogkagi, konad ogkaparas: If a person is talking, he cannot continue talking if another person squelches the one speaking. He is the one who overrides his own speech.
Ka otow no ogboboli to bogas dio to Pati: As for the person who is going to buy rice in Patil when there is no rice because the stores sold out, he just returns empty handed having gone to buy when there wasn't any rice.
Ka otow no kono ogtu-u to bohog to du-on: As for the person who doesn't believe a warning that there are raiders, he will be ensnared by something bad because he will be murdered.
Ka otow no nanumbaloy dio to songo ugpa-: A person who visited another place, didn’t stay very long then he returned home. If he stayed three days then he returned.
Ka otow no manokal no wa do nigbuoy no n: A person who was strong with little time elapse, he was able to finish his field.
Ka kommag to otow no buriak pigdayandaya: As for the buriak spear, the shaft has been decorated and has been wrapped with bronze to make the shaft beautiful (lit. good to see) up to the reinforced tip.
Ka patiukan, tamo-ing tamusan, woy ka ta: The honey bees patiukan, tamo-ing tamusan and the wasps tabu-uan, lapinid, baga-baga, all have grubs. Those are their offspring.
Ko ogkaboros ka boi, ogburut ka gotok di: When a woman is pregnant, her stomach protrudes; that is it becomes rounded.
Ka bato, oghiupon dan ka paburut oyow og: As for the children, they blow up the balloon so that it will become rounded as it inflates.
Pinangapanga ka pogsagunut to boi to bul: A woman divided her hair into two parts as she was she was rolling her hair into [two] pompadours [on her head].
Ka pabu ka natagaan ku no manuk no ogbur: A turkey is the only “chicken” I know of that fluffs up. When it sees a person it fluffs itself up.
Ko nigbinulan si Elena dio to Davao, pig: When Elena worked as a housegirl in Davao, she was given instructions to pour water on the flowers.
No pogbus-ug din to woig, no nasubid ka: As she was pouring the water on the flowers, a lapinid wasp nest got wet and so she was stung.
Kono nu ogpinpinnu-ui ka agology no song: Don’t sit on the sack of corn because it will spill out.
Pour out the corn which you will dry.
Ka otow no du-on pi-ot, busug woy tunud: A person who has a bow and arrow set, that is a bow and arrow which is used to shoot if there is a blind for the birds.
Kono ki ogbaloybaloy to mgo boi. Ogbusun: Let's not take up residence with women. We will be cursed.
Ko ogtu-uron nu to ogbutung, og-inso-on: If you purpose to make a purchase transaction, you will inquire and if [the other person] will give it, you will buy it.
Ko ogbogoy, ogkabutung nu ka nati to kud: If the [other person] agrees, you will make the purchase transaction.
Dio to kanami, woy ogkatahuron noy ko no: In our place, we don't show respect to someone unless they have been made a leader.
Nabuyagoy on ka homoy dio to liang; nabu: The rice was spilled and scattered from the basket; it was spilled and then scattered on the ground.
Ka mgo balubato woy ka mgo dalaga, ko du: As for the unmarried men and the unmarried women, if there is a necklace or a bracelet of a leg band which they covet, they will be quick to ask for it.
Ka sika abalangon, ungod oglibonglibong: As for that relentless pursuing, an unmarried man keeps coming back until he can obtain that which he is requesting. It is like the person from whom he is begging is being forced to give.
Dakol so goinawa ni Donghuan su nahan di: Donghuan was scared to death because he was thinking, “I will probably be eaten by this big python.”
Sagboka rò no boi ka indakoli rin to goi: There is only one woman whom he loves.
Ko du-on mgo batò no ogko-on no moon-ing: If there are children who are eating and there is a lot of rice which falls to the floor, they are wasting the food.
Du-on otow no nigulak to konò no baloy r: There was a person who dismantled what wasn't his house and he destroyed the walls.
Ian to nabunù ka asawa ku su si Apù ka d: The reason my husband was murdered was because he was affected by the actions of Grandfather. That was the cause of the trouble.
Ko du-on otow no ogma-agbot to oghipanow: If someone walks heavily and stomps their feet, those of us who are sleeping will be awakened.
Ko du-on kuddò no ogpallaguy, ogdabokdab: If a horse runs, it makes a galloping sound.
Ko diò ogbayò ka duma ta to limang to da: If our companion passes on the other side of a trail, we will pass on this side as we hurry to meet him.
Ko du-on magaliug ta, ogdagap ka songo b: If we have a guest, those in another house hurry over to meet them and find out [about them].
Ko du-on duma ta no matallong ka oghipan: If we have a companion who walks fast, we will hurry fast to catch up [with him.]
Ko ogkasagboka-an kid on, ogparagas kid: When we have been there for a day, we will continue on to our true destination.
Ko ogparagasdagas ki no og-ulì, konò kid: If we proceed directly to go home, we won't stop at different places enroute. We will go straight home.
Ka otow no du-on tu-ud kanta, ogparagasd: The person who has a reason [to visit] us will go right ahead and tell us what his reason [for coming] is. He won't wait for the person of the house to ask the reason for his coming but he will just go ahead and say what he needs.
Ko du-on ogsugu-on ta no otow no ogpabol: If we send someone to buy salt then he will come back without delay. After he makes the purchase, he will turn around and come right back.
Ko moon-ing ka lawo-lawò to talubagì, og: If there are a lot of dirty spider webs, we brush off the webs of the spiders so that they will be removed. When you brush them off, the debris drops to the floor.
Ko du-on ogsisigupan, ko ogko-opus [ka s: When someone smokes, when the [cigarette] is finished burning, its ashes will drop off.
Ka banug no ogngaranan to mandagit, maga: The eagle/hawk which is called a bird of prey is quick to swoop down and snatch the chicken’s chicks when it preys on them.
Konò ka ogdagkot kanak su oghalinan ka t: Don’t be in physical contact with me because you will catch my illness.
Our feet did not touch the cement.
Heaven and earth adjacent to each other.
Pinogharok ka gotok dan no darua. Ka dan: Their two stomachs were touching (lit. kissing) each other.
Diò ki ogdahag to songo bubungan su moon: We will sleep outside on the ground on a certain mountain because there are many pigs I know about there.
Ko du-on mgo buyag no ogpanangnangonoy,: If there are older people carrying on a conversation, there are younger people who are paying close attention as they listen.
Ka mgo otow no niglo-inlo-in to kinagian: The people whose languages became different, they were not being able to comprehend each other. They didn’t understand each other.
Ka sikan no ig-agpas, igdagusu nu ka oto: That word ig-agpas, you rush a person so that they will quickly finish something.
Ka otow no nigdaldal on to maagbut no ka: As for the house of a person which was leaning due to a strong wind, it was braced by its owner so that his house would not fall over.
Ko du-on ka oghipanow, ogdalapanan ki ka: When there are those traveling, we feel rushed as they are leaving.
Ogkapolodpolod pad ka pogtakang din no o: The child repeatedly topples as it takes steps as it approaches its mother.
Ko ogdangdangon, ogdalapon ta to hauy ka: When we place something over the fire, we expose it to the heat of the fire so that it can be used for wrapping food.
Konò kow amana ogli-ag diò to tanò su og: Don't play so much outside because you will happen to be in the path of evil spirit(s) which are en route to check out a dead person.
Ko du-on og-iow to babuy, kalabow, kuddò: If someone is butchering a pig, water buffalo, or horse, we will command someone, “Go check it out because someone has butchered a pig. Get even one kilo.”
The moon has passed the zenith.
If you have insomnia, you cannot sleep. You are always tossing and turning as you lay there and you are always sweating until it becomes morning.
Ka mgo upa no manuk, songo ogpammokak ka: The hens of the chicken, they likewise cluck as they express agreement with the rooster who is crowing.
Ogdalong ki to og-u-uranda. Og-osonon ta: We enter into the one singing a love song. We encourage them by saying, “Continue singing love songs.” By that means, we are entering into our mutual joy.
Agad konon duma ta no namatoy ko ogdalon: Even if it isn't our companion who has died if we empathize with their sorrow by weeping.
Ogdalonò ki diò to tanò; diò kid ogpokoh: We will sleep outside on the ground; we will lay down there.
Ka otow no ogdangag to bailan, og-amut s: People who attend a spirit ceremony of a shaman, meet together as they listen to whatever the shaman is telling them.
Ka otow no dakol ka ogko-on, ogkagi ka s: As for a person who eats a lot, someone would say, "This person is too much who has nothing else to do than to be always eating.
Di ka nigdangatan, to pogbantoy ran, sik: But what happened to the one they were watching, that was the same thing which happened to their own offspring.
Ka mgo otow no nigkamot to landingan, ni: The people who are cutting the airstrip are lined up side by side facing upriver.
Oghinarang ki to hapuy ko oghagsilan ki: We warm ourselves by a fire if we are chilled when it is soon to dawn.
Ka kalu-agi to lawa to kamulung, marani: The width of the body to the beetle is nearly one inch.
Ka aubakbakoy, ogmarani on ogpokog-unawa: The adolescent frog is becoming almost the same size as the mother in size.
Ko og-otian on ka nigsamba no woig, song: When the flooded [river] water has receeded, the thickness of the silt is a handspan deep.
Ko du-on pagko-onan to ogpangasawa, no k: When there is a wedding feast, and if there are some who are lacking rice (lit. food), we add to the rice for those who had insufficient.
Ogdanntoy on ka allow ko ogliu on to bub: The sun is setting when it goes past the mountain as it is disappearing over the horizon.
Ko og-init ki to woig, igdapig ta su ogh: When we heat water, we set it aside because we allow the water to cool off.
Ka mgo manukmanuk ogdapù to mgo bogas to: The birds flock together feeding on the fruits of the tree.
Ko daral dò, lo-in on no lituk su ogdagu: If the word is just daral, it's meaning is different because we are rushing our companion to do something.
Ko ogkasaklupan ka to mausilom, mohirap: If you are caught on the trail at nighttime, it is difficult for you to get to your place because your pathway is dark.
Maroyow sikandin no otow su igparatong d: He is a good person because he makes sure that the money reaches the owner of the corn.
Ko oggabas, ogkanokal ki ko ogpandayagan: When we saw a log, we exert effort when we strain to pull back on the saw.
When someone is in labor, the mother strains with much effort.
Ian to oghingaranan ka sikan no kayu to: The reason why that tree is called dayuan is because the birds flock to it to pluck the baliti fruit.
Ko ogkarayunan on ka ogkamatoy, konad on: When a person who is dying goes into a coma, he is unaware when we try to arouse him.
Ko du-on otow no oghipanow no ogdabokdab: If a person walks and stomps, his steps are loud and we are awakened.
Ogkohonat ka pa-a ta ka ogtakang ki woy: Our foot is lifted up as we take a step and then we step down.
Ko du-on ka mgo pinamula ta no mgo bulak: If we have plants which are flowers, we will be careful when we step so that the flowers won't be accidentally stepped on.
Ogdiri-ok ki to homoy no naga-ani oyow i: We trample the rice stems which have been harvested so that the grains of rice can be dried in the sun.
Ogdilin a atag to wangal su masamuk. Kon: I, however, avoid scandals because they make trouble. We shouldn't get involved in scandals about other people.
Ka manggianak, ogdilin to ko-onon no igh: As for a nursing mother, she abstains from eating foods served at someone else's house in case it might cause the child to die.
Sikan ka indilin to Magbobo-ot kandan to: Those were the animals God forbade them to eat.
Ko ogdilinan ki ogsaparan ki oyow kono k: If we are forbidden we are negatively-commanded not to do what we were told not to do.
Dilipa nu ka balanghuy su igdampil tad o: Slice the cassava thinly because we will dry it after a while.
Ko du-on ogpamminogan ta ogpadingil ki t: When we are listening to something, we cock our heads so that we can hear clearly.
Kagi to inoy, \"Kai ka su ogpamminog a t: His mother said, "Come here because I will listen to your stomach to find out why your stomach is growling."
Ko mariù ka ugpa-an to duma ta, ko ogpan: If the place where our companion lives is far away, and if I would have liked to visit, it will be too far for me to go. I won’t be able to manage to go to that place because it is too far.
Nigdinog si Apù Amasig to nasasow a to g: Grandfather Amasig heard that I was worried about my saw.
Warad otow, warad ogdinogon ta no ogkaka: There were no more people; there was no more talking which we could hear.
We cause [people] to hear what we have to say.
The pots clanged as they hit each other.
Ka otow no oglogsad to tanò, ko ogpakaro: As for a person who is stepping down to the ground from his house, if he hears the call of a dove at the same time, he/she will not go ahead with climbing down.
If there is food there, there are people to be fed by you.
I am here beside you; I am here.
Nigkita kai ka notebook no du-on kai to: I saw the notebook which was here on top of the table.
Ko og-anad ki to batò to ogsulat to ngar: When we teach a child to write his/her name, we say, Do it like this to write. Included in the meaning is our demonstration as we teach.
Ko og-ogotan ki to duma ta, ognangon ka: Why did you behave like that toward your companion when he didn't have a fault to you?
Think about me. [Take care of me.]
Ko ogkadugi ka pa-a ta, ogkuiton ta to d: If we get a thorn in our foot, we will pick it out with a needle so that it will be removed.
Ka bakotin, ogdugnalon ka susu oyow ogda: The piglet butts up against the tits so that the milk will become greater.
We have inadvertently interrupted you because you are eating.
Ko sikan pad ogbunsuri no ogga-ani, konò: When someone has just begun to harvest, other people cannot go there because the harvesters will suffer the negative result of being interrupted and become ill.
Nighun-a on nig-uli si ino su nigdugsuna: Mother returned home first because her breasts were already engorged with milk.
It is a tree that when struck with a knife its body bleeds.
Ko diò to Kapugi, ka woig, ogduhu. Ko to: If [one is] in Kapugi, the water rises. In respect to trees which replace their leaves, they shed.
Ka Liboganon, woy ogduhù ko oglanog. Ka: The [water] of the Liboganon River doesn’t rise unless it floods. The [water] of the ocean rises but it still remains clear.
Ko mahapun on to alas tris, ogdukimot be: When it is already afternoon [about] three o’clock, the sun becomes obscured and the thunder clouds become dark.
Pigdukdukulan ka batò no nigko-on to dul: The child who ate dulian fruit overate; his chest was hurting.
Nigdulduliak on ka asawa ni usi ko og-or: When Usì’s wife sows rice seed, she casts in all directions.
Ko ogdulu ka kayu, ogkapadpad ka doun ko: When a tree sheds its leaves, the leaves drop off when the wind blows against them.
The person next to me is my wife.
I moved next to Father to sleep.
If one moves very close, they are very near each other.
Ogdurulugdulug so-i bogas to mundù su ma: These sweet potatoes are crowding each other because they have many tubers (lit. fruits).
They are inadvertently sitting next to each other.
The lovers are moving close to each other.
Ko ogduruldulugan ta ka duma ta, kanta k: If we approach someone we are the ones to come close to him.
Ka lawa to barku, ka dulung, sikan ka og: As for the body of a ship, the bow, that is what goes first.
Ko niglogsad on ka ariplano no nigbulig: When the plane landed and the people helped deliver your things to the house, they took them all the way to the house. They took them directly upstairs. This is considered an act of service for which there is no charge.
Ogduluson ki to babuy no ogkannugunan to: We are chased by a pig which is protecting its offspring.
We didn’t know that others would arrive.
Ko ogmarakdakoloy to goinawa to duma ta,: If we love our neighbors (lit. companion), they will also love us.
Nahan din no ogduma koykow diò to Nasuli: She assumes that she will accompany you to Nasuli.
Bring all of your children here...
Ko ogdumoon ka diò to dangob no talabau,: If you are taken along to another work, you are drawn over to it.
Ko warò ig-ogot nu to duma nu, ogma-agka: If there is nothing for which you would clash with your companion, our interpersonal relationships will be good.
Natampod ka pogdumaruma ta su diò kid to: Our companionship has been cut off because we live far from each other.
Ogdungdung ka kayu no marani to woig. Og: The tree by the water is leaning over. Its tip is upside down.
Those who are being deloused are being leaned over.
Ka tikò, songo ogdungko-dungkò ko oggong: The tikò insect moves its head up and down when we hold onto its body.
Don't slouch; don't be bent over.
We will hunker down if we hide.
Ogpakarungkù ki su ogkahallok ki no ogki: We have to be hunkered down because we are afraid that we might be seen.
Buyagbuyag bua ka miow dut kuddo?: Is the cat perhaps older than the horse?
Tigbal ki rò nigpinnu-u ka ogko-on no no: We had just barely sat down when guests arrived and caught us as we were eating.
Ko du-on og-oggung, kandin dò ka ogduyug: When someone sings oggung style, the one who sings to an accompaniment is the same one who plays the saluroy instrument.
Ka gamut, agad nokoy ka ogpokohilu, unaw: As for poison, whatever is able to poison such as tayuran.
As for others, rat poison can poison an enemy.
Ka gamut, ogsabukan ki oyow maga-an ki o: As for a hex, it is placed on us so that we will quickly die.
Ko oglaba ki to manggad, agad warò amana: When we wash clothes, even if there isn't very much sunshine we can still dry them in the sun because they will still become dry if they will be blown in the wind.
Ko iam ka ganat, konò ogkakanat su mabog: If or when a spring is new, it cannot be stretched because it is strong.
Sampulù koy no otow ka ogpagagantioy to: We are ten people who will reciprocally help one another to cut fields.
Ogganuyon ta ka balagon ko og-ulì ki diò: We drag the rattan when we return to the house.
Ko ogpalawod ki to gakit diò to dibabò,: When we go downriver by raft, when we return we pull the gakit in going upriver against the current.
Ogkoirapan ka kalabow no ogganuy to kang: The carabao which is pulling a cart as it hauls corn will experience difficulty if there are those who ride on it.
Ko du-on jeep no nasirà no awos no og-al: If there is a jeep which is broken down which needs to be taken to a shop for repair, they also have it towed by another jeep.
Ka diò to Sulit, Langilan, Banuwaloy, Ka: Those in Sulit, Langilan, Banuwaloy, Kapugi, and Pipisan, that is the word they use.
Ko du-on darua no ogpalawod no ka sagbok: If there are two people who are going downriver by raft and one goes ahead of the other, the one left behind will chase the one which got ahead and will catch up with him.
Ko du-on ka ogpalaguy, oggapunan ta oyow: If someone is fleeing, we pursue them so that we will catch up with them.
Ka makopal no gapun no mo-itom, kibol. O: The thick, black clouds are thunderheads. Those will cause it to rain.
Ka mo-ilom no kibol, ko ogmapotì on, ogl: The black thunderheads, if they become white, they will cause it to rain hard.
Ka bilisbilis, ligkat to salagapun no og: The misty rain, it comes from the fog which drips.
Ka bulu, oggasapon to otow ka ig-alabat: Smooth bamboo is cut and trimmed by a person to use to make a wall for his house.
Ka otow no magasò, warad amana sapù to l: The person who is emaciated has hardly any flesh left on his or her body.
The corn will be skinny. The ears will be small.
Pananglitan, ko du-on ogpangasawa, no ia: For example, if someone is getting married, the only thing they will be discussing is how much brideprice they will give up front for that girl.
Ko oggasa-an ka otow, oggatow ka pangkul: When a person becomes emaciated, the side of his hip bone protrudes
Ka otow no gatawan, ogkito-on ka ugat to: As for the person who has many visible veins, his veins can be seen because they protrude.
That's all right because I will just return soon.
Ka siin no atop no ninipisi, maga-an ogk: As for aluminum roofing which is very thin, it easily becomes dented when we step on it as we are using it to make a roof.
We had a saw which was an instrument for cutting off the roofing.
Du-on otow no niggabas to kayu no togop: There was a person who was sawing togop wood into boards.
We'll be cursed for wasting the rice.
Ka gabi-i no allow ka allow no nigligad: Yesterday is the day which has just passed.
Ko oggagasan ta ka lama, agad nokoy ka i: When we clear debris from the yard, anything can be used to shove aside the fallen leaves and then we carry it to a far place.
Ka nagagasan no bo-ugan, nalimud ka mgo: As for a stream that was cleared of debris, the debris was gathered together at the side of the stream.
Ko du-on ogdatong no otow no oggutasan,: If someone arrives at someone's house who is hungry, he is given something to eat from the leftovers to temporarily satiate his hunger. Then the host/hostess cooks again that which he/she will feed their guests.
Igggagow ku to gutas ku no ogko-on to do: I eat something to satiate my hunger and so I eat a little so that my hunger will be held off.
I had to eat some food to temporarily satiate my hunger.
Ko napolis poron ka pa-a nu no agpas ka: When your foot almost slipped from the step and you quickly grabbed something, you were almost .....??.... You didn't quite continue to fall from the stairs.
Amana ka so-ini no hagoran no makagagawa: This stupid stairway which scares so that I nearly fell.
Du-on batò no magalat ka ngipon din. Ka: There is a child whose teeth are far apart. His teeth have spaces between them.
Ko oghimu ka to bogyas, magalat. Magalat: When you make a fish trap, it is loosely woven. The body of the fishtrap is loosely woven and the prongs are also far apart.
Ko oglo-ug ka inoy to batò no oghilamon,: When the mother of a child goes to weed [her field], she leaves her child in the care of someone else and that person watches over him/her.
Si Taganay ka niggalatan to anak ni Lita: Taganay is the one who took care of Lita's children who were left behind.
Ka inoy, oggalatan to homoy no igpalugaw: A mother leaves rice behind for gruel to be fed to her child.
Ko ogkamatoy ki, ka mgo kalaglagan ta og: When we die, our possessions are simply left behind and cannot be taken where we will be after we die.
As for the body of that pula palm, we will knotch it to cultivate grubs.
Ogtagaran ta to tatolu no bulan woy ta o: We will wait three months before we look at the log which we have knotted to cultivate grubs to see if there are now white grubs.
A fistful is taking a large handful of food.
